The conversion of readily accessible chemicals into high-value-added products is a key process in industrial chemistry. This research showcases an efficient transformation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde utilizing poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) supported Pd-based catalysts. The catalyst’s properties were thoroughly characterized using FT-IR, SEM, TEM, XPS, and TG, confirming the successful fabrication of stable Pd/PILs catalysts. The porous architecture of the PILs material enhances palladium nanoparticle adhesion, while its structure promotes intimate contact between the catalyst and substrate, facilitating the oxidation process. With just 0.1 g of 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst, the reaction at 110 °C, 4 MPa O2 for 4 h achieve a 82.16 % conversion of benzyl alcohol with absolute selectivity to benzaldehyde. Theoretical calculations elucidated the interactions between Pd6 clusters, PIL, and benzyl alcohol. Furthermore, the Fukui function and optimized electrostatic potential diagrams identified reactive sites, providing insights into the potential reaction mechanism. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Benzyl alcohol Benzaldehyde Poly(ionic liquid)s Green oxidation Theoretical calculations Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Converting readily accessible basic chemicals into high-value-added products is crucial for expanding industrial production and advancing scientific research [1–4]. Oxidation reactions, particularly the oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes, are extensively used in various industries [5–8]. Aldehydes, as value-added chemicals, find extensive applications in various aspects of life, including food additives and fertilizers [9–12]. Among them, benzaldehyde (BzH) as an important organic intermediate in industrial production has a huge demand, and its application prospects are broad, can be widely used in medicine, spices and dyes and other fields [13–15]. Traditional industrial methods for synthesizing BzH, such as the hydrolysis of benzyl chloride and direct oxidation of toluene, often lead to environmental pollution, corrosive contamination, and low selectivity, limiting further development. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop an energy-efficient, environmentally friendly, and stable heterogeneous catalytic system for BzH synthesis. The development of a green and efficient process route for BzH synthesis based on benzyl alcohol (BzOH) has become a significant research focus. Researchers have developed various catalysts for the selective oxidation of BzOH to BzH, including supported precious metals, non-precious metals, transition metal oxides, and others [16–18]. Notably, the Kong research team achieved a green oxidation of BzOH to BzH using a Pd/Fe3O4@mCeO2 magnetic core-shell nanopalladium catalyst [19]. This heterogeneous catalyst facilitates easy separation and recovery. With only 2.6 % Pd microspheres, the oxidation of BzOH to BzH at 100 °C and atmospheric pressure, achieving a BzOH conversion rate of 80.5 % and a BzH selectivity of 94.8 %. In the case of supported bimetallic catalysts, the synergistic effect between the metals enhances the catalytic reaction. The Alshammari research team utilized TiO2 nanostructures as carriers for Pd-Cu [20]. TiO2 is a popular catalyst support due to its superior oxygen storage function, redox performance, and ability to disperse metals. The synergistic effect of bimetallic Pd-Cu improved the activity and deactivation resistance of the catalyst. The 1 % Pd-Cu catalyst synthesised by sol-immobilisation on TiO2 showed 35.9 % conversion of BzOH and 98.7 % selectivity of BzH after heating at 120 °C for 2 h. The Thao team discovered that a sepiolite-supported Cr catalyst exhibited excellent performance in the BzOH to BzH oxidation system [21]. Increasing the calcination temperature of the catalyst leads to deformation of the seafoam fibres and interaction between Cr(III) and the carrier, which improves the reusability of the catalyst. The sepiolite-supported chromium oxidation catalyst effectively catalyzed the BzOH to BzH oxidation, reaching a maximum BzOH conversion rate of about 60–70 % and maintaining a BzH selectivity of 99 % under solvent-free conditions. In the selective oxidation of BzOH to prepare BzH, it is crucial to synthesize a heterogeneous catalyst that offers high conversion, high selectivity, high stability, and ease of recycling, considering the cost and the principles of green environmental protection [22–28]. The alcohol-catalyzed oxidation to aldehyde process should meet three criteria to adhere to the principles of green chemistry: (1) the use of low-cost and readily available oxidants, such as molecular oxygen; (2) the utilization of heterogeneous catalysts that facilitate recovery and recycling; and (3) the efficiency, stability, and strong resistance to deactivation of the catalytic system [29,30]. Therefore, the selective oxidation of BzOH to BzH remains a challenge when considering these comprehensive factors. Notably, as a new polymer material, poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) with a variety of advantages can be applied to BzOH synthetic BzH systems. Ionic liquid (IL) can be synthesized into PILs material by polymerization with the cross-linking agent. PILs have the advantages of tunability, abundant ionic sites, green, structural designability, and good thermal stability, which allow PILs material to be used as excellent carriers or catalysts for catalytic reaction system [31,32]. PILs serve as excellent carriers with a rich pore structure, which enables metal nanoparticles to effectively attach to the PILs backbone. The synergistic interaction between the PILs carrier and active metals can promote efficient and selective oxidation of BzOH to produce BzH. Furthermore, PILs are recyclable and environmentally friendly, which in line with the concept of green sustainable development. A novel green catalyst, comprising Pd supported on PILs, was developed for the efficient oxidation of BzOH to produce BzH. Experimental investigations revealed that using 0.1 g of a 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst at 110 °C, under an oxygen pressure of 4 MPa for 4 h, achieved a high conversion rate of 82.16 % for BzOH with complete selectivity for BzH. Unlike conventional methods that depend on toxic or corrosive oxidants, this study utilized molecular oxygen as a benign and environmentally friendly alternative. The combination of molecular oxygen with the heterogeneous Pd/PILs catalyst system provided a more efficient and ecologically sustainable pathway for the selective conversion of BzOH to BzH. The PILs carriers were fabricated using a supercritical drying technique, preserving their intricate structure and pores, which facilitated the incorporation of Pd into the polymer matrix. The synergistic interaction between palladium and the polymer scaffold was crucial for the selective oxidation of BzOH to BzH, even in the presence of abundance molecular oxygen. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 1-Vinylimidazole (C5H6N2, 99 %) and ethylene glycol dimethacrylate (EGDMA, 98 %) were supplied by Aladdin Internet Reagent Database Co. Ltd. Benzyl chloride (C7H7Cl, AR), AIBN (AR), NaBH4 (AR), acetonitrile (C2H3N, AR), benzyl alcohol (C7H8O, 99 %), benzaldehyde (C7H6O, 99 %) and anhydrous ethanol (C2H6O, AR) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of functionalized IL The synthesis of the ionic liquid (IL) commenced with the addition of 1-vinylimidazole (5 mmol), benzyl chloride (7.5 mmol), and 8 mL of acetonitrile to a Schlenk tube. The choice of reaction rations was based on stoichiometric considerations to ensure optimal yield. The reaction apparatus was then heated in an oil bath maintained at 60 °C for 24 h, under continuous stirring and nitrogen gas protection to prevent oxidation. This extended reaction time was deemed necessary to ensure complete conversion of the starting materials. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was treated with ethyl acetate, resulting in the isolation of a milky yellow oily viscous liquid, the desired IL. A schematic diagram of the synthesis process is depicted in Scheme 1 . To confirm the structure of the synthesized IL, its 1H NMR spectrum was obtained and is shown in Fig. S1. 2.2.2 Synthesis of PILs The synthesis process of PIL-2 involved the copolymerization of IL and EGDMA at a molar ratio of 1:1. For this synthesis, 2.267 mmol of IL, 2.267 mmol of EGDMA, 0.025 g of AIBN, and 6 mL of anhydrous ethanol were combined in a reaction vessel. The mixture was thoroughly stirred at room temperature, and the reaction was carried out at 60 °C for 1 h, then gradually increased to 80 °C for 3 h, and finally heated to 100 °C for 20 h to complete the polymerization. Nitrogen was used for inert atmosphere protection throughout the reaction. After completion, the mixture was washed alternately with deionized water and ethanol, with the final wash using anhydrous ethanol. The resulting white solids were dried using a CO2 supercritical dryer and then ground to obtain PIL-2. Using the same synthesis method, PIL-1 (IL:EGDMA = 0:2) and PIL-3 (IL:EGDMA = 1:2) were also prepared by varying the molar ratio of IL to EGDMA. 2.2.3 Preparation of Pd/PILs To prepare the Pd/PILs catalysts, 0.5 g of PILs and 10 mL of deionized water were added to a beaker. Subsequently, a quantitatively calculated aqueous solution of H2PdCl4 was added dropwise to the beaker while continuously stirring for 24 h at room temperature. Subsequently, NaBH4 aqueous solution was added in three additions to convert Pd2+ to Pd0, which was stirred continuously for 6 h at room temperature. Upon completion of the reduction, the mixture was washed alternately with ethanol and deionized water to remove any excess NaBH4. The resulting solids were then dried in a vacuum drying oven at 70 °C for 12 h. After drying and grinding, the Pd/PILs catalysts were obtained. 2.3 Catalytic reaction procedure Quantities of the Pd/PILs catalyst, 1 mL of benzyl alcohol, and 5 mL of acetonitrile solvent were carefully added to the stainless-steel autoclave liner. Following three cycles of charging and deflating, the reactor was pressurized with oxygen to the predetermined level. The reactor was then placed within a constant temperature magnetic stirring heating sleeve and heated to the specified temperature. After the reaction was complete, the reactor was removed and allowed to cool to room temperature using a water bath. The reaction mixture was subsequently filtered to separate the liquid sample from the solid catalyst. Finally, the experimental results were qualitatively analyzed and quantitatively calculated by gas chromatography (GC). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization To confirm the successful synthesis of PIL-1, PIL-2, and PIL-3, infrared spectra were acquired in the 4000–400 cm-1 range using FT-IR spectroscopy (Nicolet IS 10). Fig. 1 illustrated the infrared spectra of the monomers and polymers. The peak at 3065 cm-1 was related to the stretching vibration of the CH bond of the unsaturated vinyl group in IL, which did not occur in the polymers due to the polymerization reaction [29,33]. The peak at 720 cm-1 was characteristic of the out-of-plane bending vibration of unsaturated CH bonds in vinyl, and the absence of this peak in PIL indicated successful polymerization. The presence of imidazole ring structure in the polymers were proved by the bands observed in the range of 1538–1680 cm-1 [34,35]. Both PILs and EGDMA monomers exhibited a sharp peak at 1723 cm−1, which corresponded to the stretching vibration of the C = O bond. In summary, FT-IR spectroscopy confirmed that the polymers were successfully synthesized. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured using a micromeritics 3 Flex analyzer and the porous characteristics of the catalyst samples were obtained. As shown in Fig. 2 A, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms showed a continuous increase in adsorption at relatively high pressures (0.6 < P/P0<1.0). The 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst sample exhibited type IV isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops, which reflected the presence of mesoporous structures [36,37]. As shown in Fig. 2B, the pore size distribution curves indicated that the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst displayed abundant mesoporous and macroporous structures, and their pore diameters were mainly distributed in the range of 10–80 nm. As demonstrated in Table S1, the structural characteristics of the catalysts were further elaborated. It was observed that the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst demonstrated more superior specific surface area and pore volume. The preceding analyses indicate that the synthesis of 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst with porous structure have been successfully synthesized. The porous structure can create favorable conditions for the adsorption of molecular oxygen. The rich pore space of 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst sample not only strengthens the degree of metal attachment, but also promotes the diffusion and transport process of the substrate, which can significantly enhance the efficiency of the catalytic reaction. The loading of palladium nanoparticles onto the polymer support was successfully observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Jem-2100F). Fig. 3 depicted the TEM images of the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst and the size distribution of the Pd nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 3A-3B, tiny palladium nanoparticles can be found distributed on the polymer carrier at different magnification scales. As shown in Fig. 3C, at the 2 nm scale, these visible particles exhibited a lattice spacing of 2.20 Å corresponding to the {111} lattice plane of the palladium metal nanoparticles, which confirmed that the palladium metal nanoparticles were successfully embedded in the carrier [38]. Statistical analysis of the particle size was carried out and it was found that the particle size dimensions of the Pd nanoparticles were mainly distributed between 1.5–3.5 nm as shown in Fig. 3D The morphology and microstructure of the catalyst were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Tescan Mira4). Fig. 4 showcases SEM images of the catalyst sample at various magnifications. As depicted in Fig. 4A-4C, the catalyst sample exhibits a unique cauliflower-like structure. This distinctive morphology fosters the formation of abundant voids and pore structures, thereby enhancing the binding of Pd to the carrier. Furthermore, SEM mapping analysis of the catalyst, as observed in Fig. 4C at a scale of 1 μm, demonstrates the uniform dispersion of elements C, O, Cl, Pd, and N throughout the PIL structure. The presence of all these elements in the SEM images indirectly signifies the successful synthesis of the Pd-containing PIL catalyst. To investigate the interaction between the metal Pd and the catalyst support, we performed an XPS analysis of the N and Pd species on the catalyst support, as illustrated in Fig. 5 . This analysis was carried out using a ThermoFischer ESCALAB 250Xi instrument on the catalyst samples. The C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV was employed for calibration purposes, allowing for the accurate determination of the Pd 3d and N 1 s peak positions. The Pd element spectra revealed that the Pd 3d5/2 energy level corresponding to Pd2+ ions was centered at approximately 337.5 eV, which is higher than the Pd 3d5/2 energy level associated with metallic Pd0, located at around 335.5 eV [20,39,40]. For the catalyst supports, we also conducted elemental spectral fitting. Initially, an XPS fit analysis of N in the PIL was carried out as depicted in Fig. 5A. According to the literature, the binding energy of CN is (∼399.45 eV) and that of C N + is (∼401.55 eV) [41–43]. There was a shift in the binding energy of the N element to lower energy values after metal loading. The electron capture property of N was most obvious on 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst. Analysis combining the binding energies of Pd and N elements confirmed the occurrence of adequate coordination between Pd and N, leading to electron interactions between N and Pd [44,45]. As illustrated in Fig. 5B, the binding energy of Pd on the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst exhibited the most pronounced shift in the positive direction, with a binding energy of 335.68 eV for Pd0 3d5/2. This observation suggests that there is a robust interaction between Pd and the N on this catalyst. Pd transferred electrons to the N of the carrier, resulting in Pd losing electrons and N gaining electrons. The enhancement in catalytic activity was in line with this trend: the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst exhibited optimal performance. The thermal stability of PIL-2 and the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 samples were evaluated using thermogravimetric analysis (TG, NETZSCH STA 409PC/PG). As shown in Fig. 6 , both the catalyst and the carrier exhibited good thermal stability. The thermal decomposition temperature of the catalyst is much higher than the experimental temperature (100–130 °C). Thermal decomposition of the catalyst to affect the catalytic performance does not occur during the reaction. As well, due to the inherent porosity of the PIL carrier, it tended to absorb moisture when exposed to air, resulting in a slight decrease in sample quality at temperatures below 100 °C. 3.2 Evaluation of catalyst performance 3.2.1 Effect of reaction variables on benzyl alcohol oxidation reaction Fig. 7 A illustrated the impact of metal Pd loading of the catalyst on the BzOH oxidation reaction. As increasing metal Pd loading in the catalyst, the conversion of BzOH demonstrated an initial upward trajectory, followed by a subsequent decline. In accordance with the established reaction conditions of 2 MPa O2, 110 °C, and 4 h, 0.1 g of the Pd/PIL-2 catalyst was introduced to the reactor. The conversion of BzOH reached a maximum value of 79.84 % at a theoretical Pd loading of 1 wt %. Excess metal Pd may accumulate on the active sites of the support, thus affecting the oxidation reaction. As illustrated in Fig. 7A, the selectivity of BzH remained unaltered at 100 % when the Pd loading on the catalyst was modified. The impact of reaction temperature on the BzOH oxidation system was further investigated in the presence of 0.1 g of 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst. Fig. 7B exhibited a trend whereby, as the reaction temperature increased, the conversion of BzOH initially rose before subsequently declining. The maximum conversion of BzOH was 79.84 % at 2 MPa O2, 110 °C and the reaction time of 4 h. However, as the temperature continued to rise, the conversion rate of BzOH tended to decrease. The observed reduction in catalytic performance could be attributed to the partial deactivation of the active sites on the catalyst at conditions of excessively high temperature. The impact of reaction time on the oxidation of BzOH was investigated under conditions of 110 °C, 0.1 g of the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst, and 2 MPa O2. Fig. 7C illustrated that the conversion of BzOH reached its maximum at 4 h. As the concentration of benzyl alcohol decreases to a certain threshold, the reaction rate becomes limited by the probability of contact between the active site and the reactants. At this critical point, extending the reaction time merely prolongs the slow reaction phase at low concentrations, resulting in limited improvement in overall conversion. Prolonged operation within a single reaction may induce temporary alterations in the catalyst surface and a reduction in the number of effective active sites, consequently leading to a slight decrease in benzyl alcohol conversion. Comprehensive analysis indicates that the catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde using 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalysts does not involve complex reaction pathways. Hence, the catalytic performance remains essentially unchanged under the conditions of further extended reaction time. Consequently, 4 h was determined as the optimal reaction duration. Oxygen pressure is a critical factor in oxidation reactions. As depicted in Fig. 7D, the effects of varying oxygen pressures on the oxidation of BzOH to BzH were investigated. As the oxygen pressure rose, the conversion rate of BzOH also increased, albeit at a slow rate. When considering the economic factors of the reaction, it was determined that 4 MPa O2 represented the optimal reaction pressure. The conversion of BzOH reached 82.16 % and the selectivity of BzH was 100 % when 0.1 g of 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst was used under the reaction conditions of 110 °C for 4 h, maintaining 4 MPa O2. The application of elevated oxygen pressure ensured adequately contact between the active oxygen molecule, the substrate, and the active sites, which could further enhance the conversion rate of BzOH. The oxygen pressure was elevated from 2 MPa to 4 MPa O2, which is considered sufficiently high to optimize the reaction. At this pressure range, oxygen and benzyl alcohol may compete for adsorption sites on the catalyst surface. However, further increasing the oxygen pressure beyond this range did not result in a significant enhancement of the catalytic performance, suggesting that the reaction is not limited by oxygen availability under these conditions. Under the optimal temperature, pressure, loading amount, and reaction duration, the impact of catalyst dosage on the oxidation of BzOH to BzH was further examined. As depicted in Fig. 7E, the BzOH conversion rate reached a maximum of 82.16 % with the addition of 0.1 g of the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst. When the catalyst dosage was further increased, no significant improvement in catalytic performance was observed. At a catalyst dosage of 0.1 g, the active sites adequately meet the kinetic demands of the reaction. In comparison to conventional catalysts, 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst ensures a high BzOH conversion rate with a notable enhancement in BzH selectivity. As depicted in Figs. 7A-7E, a significant benefit of employing a Pd/PILs catalyst system is the high degree of selectivity, which minimises the formation of by-products and enhances the purity of the desired product. 3.2.2 Catalyst stability determination The recyclability of a catalyst is a critical metric in evaluating its overall performance. In practical industrial contexts, the stability of a catalyst may be even more critical than its activity, particularly when production costs are considered [46]. As revealed by Fig. 8 , the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst proved to be the optimal selection following a comprehensive analysis of the experimental outcomes. The cycling performance of the catalyst was subjected to rigorous testing under optimal experimental conditions, consisting of 110 °C, 4 MPa oxygen, 4 h and 0.1 g catalyst dosage. It was noteworthy that the catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability, retaining high activity and stability throughout five consecutive cycle tests. As shown in Table S2, the actual metal loading of the catalysts before and after the cycling experiments was detected by ICP-OES, and the results indicated that the catalysts showed only a small amount of metal leaching after the reaction. Metal leaching is a key factor in reducing the conversion of BzOH. During the cycling experiments, the conversion rate of BzOH and the selectivity of BzH were maintained at a high level, which can provide a valuable reference direction for industrial applications. 4 Possible mechanisms The results indicated that the Pd6 cluster was the most suitable for this reaction system. This study employed the Genmer and Molclus program to determine the most stable configuration of the Pd6 cluster. The procedure involved generating 10 random Pd6 cluster structures using Genmer, followed by optimizing these structures sequentially using the Molclus program to screen and obtain the final cluster structure with practical value. In the BzOH catalytic process, the adsorption of O2 on the cluster was considered the first step in the oxidation process. Therefore, the adsorption behavior of O2 on Pd6 clusters was investigated using Gaussian 09 software. All atoms were calculated using PBE functionals: Pd atoms were assigned the def-tzvp basis set, while the remaining atoms used the B3LYP/6–311G++** basis set for geometric optimization, ensuring no imaginary frequency. Subsequently, to calculate the optimized structure energy, the def2-tzvp basis set was selected for the Pd atoms, and the B3LYP/6–311G++** basis set was used for the rest of the atoms [47]. To further determine the reaction sites, the Hirshfeld charges were calculated using Multiwfn, and the reaction sites were predicted by the Fukui function. Van der Waals electrostatic potential surface plots for all molecules were generated using Multiwfn + VMD software [48]. Chemical reactivity mainly includes regioselectivity, electrophilicity and nucleophilicity. Applying density functional theory (DFT) to assess these properties is a prevalent research approach in the literature [49]. In this study, Hirshfeld charges were calculated using the Multiwfn software, and reaction sites were predicted using Fukui functions, as detailed in Table S3. Fig. 9 presented the Fukui function for BzOH, where the intensity of the blue color indicated the likelihood of a reaction occurring. It was evident from Fig. 9 that the reaction predominantly took place near the OH bond. In the catalytic oxidation of BzOH, it is generally accepted that the adsorption of O2 on the catalyst Pd cluster is the initial step in the process. The stability of these clusters is a key factor to investigate. The average binding energy, the second difference in energy, and the energy gap between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) have been used to evaluate the stability of Pd clusters [50,51]. The average binding energy of Pdn clusters showed slight variations and did not continue to increase for n > 6. The second-order differential energies of Pdn (n = 4–6) clusters were positive, indicating good stability. Additionally, the Pd6 cluster exhibited the largest energy gap, suggesting relative stability [52]. Therefore, we initially studied the potential structures of 10 Pd6 clusters and further optimized them. After eliminating repetitive structures, we obtained the final structures of two Pd6 clusters, as shown in Fig. 10 . Comparison of their stability reveals that the structure in Fig. 10b was the most stable. The adsorption behavior of O₂ on Pd6 cluster was subjected to further investigation, and the optimized adsorption complexes were presented in Fig. 11 . O₂ molecules were adsorbed on the apical Pd atom, with O₂ acting as a charge acceptor for Pd6 and Pd6 as a charge donor. Under the influence of the Pd6 cluster, the OO bond length of the O2 molecules increased from 1.205 Å to 1.332 Å. The elongation of the OO bond was indicative of the successful adsorption of the O2 molecule onto the palladium. The increase in OO bond length facilitated the generation of reactive molecular oxygen, which accelerated the oxidation process. Similarly, we investigated the effect of the Pd6 cluster on the BzOH molecule, and the results were presented in Fig. 12 . As observed, the reaction primarily occurred near the OH bond. Under the influence of the Pd6 cluster, the OH bond length in the BzOH molecule increased from the original 0.961 to 0.978 Å. The elongation of the OH bond suggested that the OH bond was more susceptible to rupture under the influence of Pd6 cluster, thereby facilitating the reaction. The aforementioned analyses demonstrated that the Pd6 cluster facilitated the catalytic oxidation of BzOH. In this paper, PILs were used as carriers to support Pd metal and catalytically oxidize BzOH. The utilization of the PILs as carriers were more advantageous for the catalytic oxidation of BzOH than conventional catalysts. To further explain this phenomenon, quantified computing was performed and the result was presented in Fig. 13 . As demonstrated in Table S3, the Fukui function analysis indicated that the reaction occurred at the OH position of BzOH, with the OH bond being the first to break. The optimised electrostatic potential energy distribution of BzOH (Fig. 13a) demonstrated that the hydroxyl O had a pronounced capacity to absorb electrons, thereby attaining negative charges. As illustrated in Fig. 13a, the H atom directly connected to O appeared positively charged (0.154 eV) and the H on the benzene ring being positively charged (0.044 eV). The electrostatic distribution of the optimized PIL-2 fragment (Fig. 13b) showed that Cl- was highly electronegative with a strong negative charge (−0.605 eV). Hence, as BzOH interacts with PIL-2, the OH group of BzOH is inclined to position near the Cl- ion, which bears a substantial negative charge. The pronouncedly negative Cl- ion effectively attracts the positively charged H + located on the hydroxyl group. This interaction mitigates the energy involved in the OH bond, thereby enhancing the oxidation efficiency of the process. 5 Conclusions In this study, Pd/PILs catalysts were synthesized independently. The highly designable structure of PILs enables these materials to serve as effective catalyst carriers, thereby substantially broadening their range of potential applications. When compared to traditional catalysts, the Pd/PILs catalysts demonstrate enhanced catalytic properties in the BzOH catalytic oxidation system. Specifically, utilizing 0.1 g of 1 % Pd/PIL-2 as the catalyst, a BzOH conversion rate of 82.16 % was achieved with complete selectivity for BzH under reaction conditions of 110 °C, 4 MPa O2, and 4 h. Notably, the 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst facilitates easy recovery and reuse, functioning as a heterogeneous catalyst. Following multiple recycling experiments, the catalyst maintained excellent stability. Furthermore, theoretical computational studies based on the experimental findings offer a deeper insight into the reaction mechanism, providing theoretical backing for subsequent research endeavors. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of readily accessible chemicals into high-value-added products is a key process in industrial chemistry. This research showcases an efficient transformation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde utilizing poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) supported Pd-based catalysts. The catalyst’s properties were thoroughly characterized using FT-IR, SEM, TEM, XPS, and TG, confirming the successful fabrication of stable Pd/PILs catalysts. The porous architecture of the PILs material enhances palladium nanoparticle adhesion, while its structure promotes intimate contact between the catalyst and substrate, facilitating the oxidation process. With just 0.1 g of 1 % Pd/PIL-2 catalyst, the reaction at 110 °C, 4 MPa O2 for 4 h achieve a 82.16 % conversion of benzyl alcohol with absolute selectivity to benzaldehyde. Theoretical calculations elucidated the interactions between Pd6 clusters, PIL, and benzyl alcohol. Furthermore, the Fukui function and optimized electrostatic potential diagrams identified reactive sites, providing insights into the potential reaction mechanism.
